title: Film strips
brief_description: What are the most commonly used film guages? 35mm is the standard; 16mm and 8mm are favoured by amateur filmmakers; and the wide, high-resolution 70mm is most commonly used for epics by Hollywood directors.

constellations_primary.name: Analogue and digital film
constellations_primary.description: Though technology has evolved since celluloid film strips were invented, contemporary filmmakers and artists still appreciate and celebrate the analogue in a digital world.

description:
What explodes like gunpowder and made movies possible? Celluloid.

British American photographer John Carbutt developed celluloid sheets for photographic plates around 1888. They were used in cylindrical Kinetographs, but they were too stiff for motion-picture cameras. Enter Hannibal Goodwin and Kodak founder George Eastman, two New Yorkers who independently created flexible film from highly combustible nitrocellulose, which could sometimes explode in projectors! The two inventors raced each other to patent their technology, but Eastman received his patent first and began mass-producing film for Thomas Edison.

These strips are the most commonly used film gauges: 35mm is the standard; 16mm and 8mm are favoured by amateur filmmakers; and the wide, high-resolution 70mm is most commonly used for epics by Hollywood directors.
description_for_label:
What explodes like gunpowder and made movies possible? Celluloid.

British American photographer John Carbutt developed celluloid sheets for photographic plates around 1888. They were used in cylindrical Kinetographs, but they were too stiff for motion-picture cameras. Enter Hannibal Goodwin and Kodak founder George Eastman, two New Yorkers who independently created flexible film from highly combustible nitrocellulose, which could sometimes explode in projectors! The two inventors raced each other to patent their technology, but Eastman received his patent first and began mass-producing film for Thomas Edison.

These strips are the most commonly used film gauges: 35mm is the standard; 16mm and 8mm are favoured by amateur filmmakers; and the wide, high-resolution 70mm is most commonly used for epics by Hollywood directors.

group_works.title: 16mm film - Royal Family England, Changing of the Guard, colour
35mm film, movie trailers: Madagascar (2005), colour; Marie Antoinette (2006), colour
70mm film IMAX test footage: Space shuttle launch; The Rolling Stones in concert
8mm Walton Standard film - The Kansan (1943), George Archainbaud, black and white
9.5mm Cine film - The Rodeo (1933), black and white, animated
9.5mm Pathescope film - The Umbrella (1933), black and white
